title: Stabilize (only) the never type

labels.name: T-lang
labels.description: Relevant to the language team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: B-unstable
labels.description: Implemented in the nightly compiler and unstable.

labels.name: C-tracking-issue
labels.description: Category: A tracking issue for an RFC or an unstable feature.

body:
This is an alternative to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57012 that does not propose changing the type inference fallback (yet). This unblocks `TryFrom` and `TryInto` https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/33417.

#49593 has now been fixed. This was the reason for the previous revert of stabilization (#50121).

## What is being stabilized

* `!` is now a full-fledged type and can now be used in any type position (eg. [RFC 1216](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1216)). The `!` type can coerce into any other type, see https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/tree/master/src/test/run-fail/adjust_never.rs for an example.
* The `never_type` feature gate is stable, although some of the behaviours it used to gate now live behind the new `exhaustive_patterns` feature gate (see below).

## What is *not* being stabilized

* Exhaustive pattern-matching for uninhabited types. eg.

    ```rust
    let x: Result<u32, !> = ...;
    let Ok(y) = x;
    ```

  This code will still complain that `Ok(_)` is a refutable pattern. This can be fixed by using the `exhaustive_patterns` feature gate. See [RFC 1872](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1872) for progress on this issue. See https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/tree/master/src/test/ui/feature-gate-exhaustive-patterns.rs for the testcase which confirms that this behaviour is still gated.

* The type inference changes proposed in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/48950 are not part of this proposal, since they can break some previously-valid programs and the mitigations discussed in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57012 are not ready yet.

  This change is moved to a new dedicated feature gate, `inference_fallback_to_never`, instead of `never_type`.
